definitions: fresh fruits and vegetables grown for commercial sale
films, television shows, or recordings created by artistic production
examples: The farmers market sells fresh produce every Saturday morning
She carefully selected organic produce from the grocery store
The studio's latest produce includes several award-winning documentaries
His creative produce spans multiple genres and artistic mediums

definitions: person who oversees and finances the creation of films, shows, or recordings
company or person that manufactures goods for commercial sale
farmer or business that grows and supplies agricultural products
examples: The film producer secured funding for the independent movie project
She worked as an executive producer on several hit television series
China remains the world's largest producer of consumer electronics
The steel producer announced plans to expand their manufacturing facilities
Local honey producers gathered at the annual beekeepers convention
The dairy producer supplies milk to stores throughout the region

definitions: item manufactured or refined for sale to consumers
result obtained by multiplying two or more numbers together
something that results from a process or creative effort
examples: The company launched their new product line last quarter
Consumer products must meet strict safety regulations before sale
The product of twelve times five equals sixty
Students learned to calculate the product of complex algebraic expressions
Her latest novel is the product of years of research
This crisis is the product of poor planning and management

definitions: process of manufacturing or growing something on a large scale
staging or presentation of a theatrical, film, or television work
act or process of creating or bringing something into existence
examples: The factory increased production to meet holiday demand
Mass production revolutionized the automobile industry completely
The theater company's production of Hamlet received critical acclaim
She directed a lavish production at the Metropolitan Opera House
Oil production declined significantly during the economic downturn
The production of new ideas requires creative thinking and collaboration

definitions: effectiveness of productive effort measured by rate of output per unit
measure of economic performance comparing output to input resources used
examples: Employee productivity increased after implementing flexible work schedules
The new software significantly improved workplace productivity levels
Labor productivity grew by three percent last quarter nationwide
Agricultural productivity depends on soil quality and weather conditions

definitions: informal shortened form of professor used by students
examples: The prof extended the deadline for our research papers
Students lined up outside the prof's office during consultation hours
My economics prof explains complex theories really clearly
The prof cancelled today's lecture due to illness

definitions: socially offensive language including swear words and vulgar expressions
language showing disrespect or irreverence toward sacred things or religious beliefs
examples: The movie received an R rating due to excessive profanity
Parents complained about profanity in the television broadcast
Using profanity in church is considered highly inappropriate behavior
The book was banned for its profanity against religious institutions

definitions: act of declaring or claiming something openly or publicly
formal declaration of religious vows or faith commitment
examples: His professing of innocence failed to convince the jury
The professing of loyalty became a daily ritual
The monk's professing took place in the abbey chapel
Her professing of faith marked a spiritual transformation

definitions: paid occupation requiring prolonged training and formal qualification
open declaration or claim of belief, feeling, or intention
examples: Medicine has been a respected profession for thousands of years
She chose teaching as her profession after college graduation
His profession of love came as a complete surprise
The defendant made a tearful profession of remorse

definitions: person engaged in a specified activity as their main paid occupation
person competent or skilled in a particular activity at expert level
examples: The tennis professional offered private lessons at the club
Healthcare professionals worked tirelessly during the pandemic crisis
She hired a professional to redesign her website completely
Only professionals should attempt this dangerous stunt work

definitions: competence or skill expected from a professional in their field
conduct, behavior, and attitude expected in a professional setting
examples: Her professionalism impressed everyone at the board meeting
The company values professionalism in all customer interactions
The surgeon's professionalism was evident in every procedure performed
Athletes must maintain professionalism both on and off field

definitions: teacher of the highest rank in a college or university department
person who professes to be an expert in some art or science
examples: The professor published groundbreaking research on climate change
Students eagerly enrolled in the popular professor's philosophy course
He became a professor of modern art despite lacking credentials
The self-proclaimed professor offered dubious investment advice online

definitions: position or post of a professor at a university
named or endowed position for a distinguished academic scholar
examples: She accepted a professorship at Harvard University last year
The professorship requires both teaching and research responsibilities
The alumni association funded an endowed professorship in economics
He holds the Einstein professorship in theoretical physics

definitions: high degree of skill or expertise in a particular area
demonstrated ability to perform a task at an acceptable standard
examples: Language proficiency is required for international business positions
The test measures proficiency in mathematics and reading comprehension
Her proficiency with computer programming impressed potential employers
Pilots must demonstrate proficiency before receiving their license

definitions: outline or contour of something, especially a person's face from the side
concise biographical or descriptive summary of a person or organization
collection of data or characteristics describing something or someone
examples: The artist sketched her profile in charcoal perfectly
The mountain's profile stood out against the sunset sky
The magazine published a profile of the new CEO
His dating profile mentioned his love of hiking
Police developed a psychological profile of the suspect
The customer profile helps target marketing campaigns effectively

definitions: process of analyzing data to identify patterns or characteristics
controversial practice of targeting individuals based on stereotypes
technical process of creating shaped edges or contours
examples: Customer profiling helps businesses understand their target market
DNA profiling solved the decades-old cold case mystery
Racial profiling by police remains a contentious civil rights issue
Airport security profiling raised concerns about discrimination
The carpenter specializes in decorative wood profiling techniques
Metal profiling creates precise edges for industrial components

definitions: financial gain from business activity after deducting expenses
advantage or benefit gained from something beyond monetary value
examples: The company reported record profits last quarter impressively
Small businesses struggle to maintain profit during economic downturns
She found little profit in continuing the argument further
Reading widely will profit you throughout your entire life

definitions: state or condition of yielding financial gain or profit
ability of a business to generate earnings relative to costs
examples: The startup achieved profitability within eighteen months surprisingly
Profitability analysis revealed several underperforming product lines
Long-term profitability requires strategic planning and market adaptation
The merger improved profitability for both companies significantly

definitions: extremely large quantity or amount of something
extravagant or abundant display of objects or qualities
examples: The garden displayed a profusion of colorful wildflowers
A profusion of choices made the decision surprisingly difficult
The wedding featured a profusion of exotic floral arrangements
Her writing shows a profusion of creative metaphors throughout

definitions: direct ancestor or predecessor in a family lineage
person or thing that first originates or gives rise to something
examples: DNA testing revealed their common progenitor lived centuries ago
The family traced their lineage to a progenitor in Scotland
Darwin is considered the progenitor of evolutionary theory
This early computer was the progenitor of modern technology

definitions: children or descendants of a person, animal, or plant
products or outcomes that result from something
examples: The monarch's progeny ruled various European kingdoms for generations
Scientists studied the progeny of genetically modified plants carefully
These modern technologies are the progeny of earlier innovations
His philosophical progeny influenced thinkers for centuries afterward

definitions: medical assessment predicting the likely course and outcome of a disease
sign or indication of a future event or trend
examples: The doctor's prognostic suggested a full recovery was likely
Blood tests provide important prognostic information about cancer
Economic prognostics point toward continued market volatility ahead
These symptoms serve as prognostics of more serious conditions

definitions: planned series of activities, events, or procedures
set of coded instructions enabling a computer to perform tasks
television or radio show broadcast as scheduled entertainment
examples: The training program lasts twelve weeks in total
Schools implemented new literacy programs this academic year
She wrote a program to automate data analysis tasks
The program crashed due to a memory overflow error
My favorite program airs every Thursday at eight o'clock
The nature program won several documentary awards recently

definitions: act of scheduling or planning programs and activities
process of writing computer code to create software applications
examples: Television programing changes during holiday seasons significantly
The festival programing includes concerts and art exhibitions
She learned programing through online coding bootcamps
Programing requires logical thinking and attention to detail

definitions: organized plan of activities or events over time
printed booklet listing events, participants, or performance details
television or radio broadcast show or series
examples: The conference programme includes keynote speakers and workshops
The government launched a programme to reduce unemployment
She bought a programme at the theater entrance
The concert programme listed all performers and musical pieces
The BBC programme examines climate change impacts globally
Children's programmes air every Saturday morning on television

definitions: person who writes and tests computer code for software applications
person who plans and organizes broadcast schedules or events
examples: The programmer fixed the bug in less than an hour
Silicon Valley programmers command high salaries for their expertise
The television programmer scheduled prime-time shows strategically
Radio programmers select music based on audience demographics

definitions: process of designing and writing computer code for applications
selection and scheduling of television or radio content
organization and planning of events or educational activities
examples: She studied programming at a prestigious technology institute
Object-oriented programming revolutionized software development practices
Network programming targets specific demographic audiences strategically
Late-night programming includes talk shows and comedy specials
Educational programming helps children develop critical thinking skills
The museum's programming includes workshops and lecture series

definitions: process of developing gradually toward a more advanced state
movement forward through space or time continuously
sequence of things following a logical or natural order
examples: The disease showed rapid progression despite treatment efforts
Career progression requires continuous learning and skill development
The parade's progression through downtown took three hours
We watched the storm's progression across the radar screen
The chord progression creates the song's emotional impact
Mathematical progressions follow predictable numerical patterns consistently

definitions: person who advocates for social reform and progress
someone who favors new ideas and continuous improvement
member or supporter of politically liberal or left-leaning movements
examples: Early progressives fought for workers' rights and women's suffrage
Educational progressives promoted child-centered learning approaches nationwide
Technology progressives embrace innovation and disruptive change eagerly
Business progressives champion sustainable and ethical practices globally
Political progressives support universal healthcare and income equality
Young progressives mobilized voters through social media campaigns

definitions: political and social philosophy advocating reform and human advancement through government action
historical movement seeking to address problems caused by industrialization and urbanization
examples: American progressivism emerged during the early twentieth century
Modern progressivism emphasizes environmental and social justice issues
Educational progressivism transformed teaching methods in many schools
Economic progressivism advocates for wealth redistribution policies

definitions: action of legally forbidding something by law or rule
act or practice of forbidding something from happening
period in American history when alcohol sale was banned
examples: The prohibition of smoking in public buildings protects health
International prohibition of certain weapons prevents mass casualties
Parents issued a prohibition against watching television before homework
The school's prohibition on cell phones remains controversial
Prohibition lasted from nineteen twenty to nineteen thirty-three
Speakeasies flourished during Prohibition despite legal risks

definitions: person who supported the prohibition of alcohol historically
person who advocates for banning specific substances or activities
examples: Prohibitionists believed alcohol caused society's moral decay
Famous prohibitionists included Carrie Nation and Frances Willard
Modern prohibitionists campaign against marijuana legalization efforts
Drug prohibitionists argue that legalization increases addiction rates

definitions: planned piece of work designed to achieve particular aims
subsidized housing development for low-income residents
piece of research or creative work assigned to students
examples: The construction project will create hundreds of new jobs
Our team completed the project ahead of schedule successfully
She grew up in the housing projects of Chicago
The city renovated several public housing projects recently
Students presented their science projects at the annual fair
The group project requires collaboration among team members

definitions: object propelled through air especially as a weapon
missile or ammunition designed to be fired from a weapon
examples: The physics class calculated the projectile's trajectory and velocity
Ancient warriors used stones as projectiles in battle
Modern projectiles can travel at supersonic speeds accurately
Artillery projectiles caused extensive damage during the bombardment

definitions: estimate or forecast of a future situation based on current trends
display of an image on a surface using light
unconscious transfer of one's own feelings onto others
examples: Sales projections for next quarter look promising overall
Weather projections show warming temperatures throughout the region
The projection of slides enhanced the professor's lecture
Movie projection technology has evolved from film to digital
His anger was actually a projection of his own insecurity
Psychological projection often occurs in interpersonal conflicts unconsciously

definitions: person who operates film or digital projection equipment in cinemas
technician who manages visual projection equipment for presentations
examples: The projectionist ensured smooth transitions between movie reels
Digital technology reduced the need for traditional projectionists
The conference projectionist handled all audiovisual equipment professionally
Our projectionist coordinates multimedia presentations for corporate events

definitions: electronic device that projects images onto a screen or surface
mechanical device for showing films in theaters or venues
examples: The classroom projector displays presentations from laptops wirelessly
We bought a home projector for movie nights outdoors
The vintage film projector still works perfectly after restoration
Modern digital projectors replaced traditional film projectors gradually

definitions: medical condition where an organ falls from its normal position
downward displacement of a body part from its usual position
examples: Pelvic organ prolapse affects many women after childbirth
The patient underwent surgery to repair the rectal prolapse
Uterine prolapse can cause discomfort and urinary problems
Doctors diagnosed mitral valve prolapse during routine examination

definitions: member of the working class who sells labor for wages
person belonging to the industrial wage-earning class in Marxist theory
examples: Proletarians united to demand better working conditions historically
The novel depicts proletarian life in industrial England
Marxist theory predicted proletarian revolution against capitalist oppression
Proletarian movements shaped twentieth-century political landscapes significantly

definitions: social class of wage-earners in industrialized societies collectively
class of industrial workers who lack capital ownership in Marxist theory
examples: The proletariat organized strikes for better wages and conditions
Industrial revolution created a distinct urban proletariat class
Marx believed the proletariat would overthrow capitalist systems
The proletariat's struggle inspired revolutionary movements worldwide

definitions: rapid increase in number or spread of something
spread of nuclear weapons to additional countries or groups
rapid reproduction or multiplication of cells or organisms
examples: The proliferation of smartphones changed communication patterns globally
Social media enabled proliferation of misinformation rapidly
Nuclear proliferation remains a serious international security concern
Treaties aim to prevent proliferation of biological weapons
Cell proliferation occurs normally during growth and healing
Cancer involves uncontrolled proliferation of abnormal cells

definitions: separate introductory section of a literary or dramatic work
event or action that leads to another more important one
examples: The novel's prologue introduces the main character's childhood
Shakespeare often used prologues to set the scene
These protests were merely a prologue to revolution
The border skirmish proved a prologue to full war

definitions: action of extending the duration of something beyond normal limits
state of being lengthened or continued for additional time
examples: The prolongation of negotiations frustrated both parties significantly
Medical advances allow prolongation of life beyond natural limits
Unnecessary prolongation of the meeting annoyed everyone present
The prolongation of suffering raised ethical questions about treatment

definitions: formal dance event for high school or college students
paved public walkway along a waterfront or seaside
examples: She wore a stunning gown to her senior prom
The prom committee decorated the gymnasium beautifully
Tourists strolled along the prom enjoying ocean views
The seaside prom features shops and entertainment venues

definitions: leisurely walk taken in a public place for pleasure or display
paved public walk typically in a park or along a waterfront
formal march of guests at the opening of a formal ball
examples: Evening promenades along the river became their daily ritual
Victorian couples took promenades to see and be seen
The oceanfront promenade stretches for three miles beautifully
Street performers entertain crowds on the busy promenade
The debutante ball began with a formal promenade
Dancers performed the grand promenade in period costumes

definitions: state of being important, famous, or noticeable
physical feature that projects outward from its surroundings
examples: She rose to prominence in the technology industry rapidly
The scandal brought unwanted prominence to the organization
The rocky prominence offered spectacular views of the valley
A bony prominence on his forehead required medical attention

definitions: practice of engaging in sexual activity with multiple partners frequently
quality of mixing or mingling indiscriminately without careful selection
examples: Studies examined the health risks associated with sexual promiscuity
Victorian society strongly condemned promiscuity in women particularly
The promiscuity of the data sources compromised research validity
Genetic promiscuity in bacteria enables rapid evolution

definitions: declaration or assurance that one will do something specific
indication of future success or good results
grounds for expecting something favorable to happen
examples: She kept her promise to visit every summer faithfully
Politicians often break campaign promises after elections unfortunately
The young athlete shows great promise for Olympic competition
Early test results show promise for the new treatment
Dark clouds held the promise of much-needed rain
Spring brings the promise of renewal and growth

definitions: piece of promotional material or publicity for a product
short advertisement or trailer promoting something
examples: The band released a promo video for their new single
Radio stations received promo copies before the official release
Television promos for the series generated significant viewer interest
The thirty-second promo aired during prime time slots

definitions: high point of land projecting into a body of water
prominent mass of land overlooking lower land or water
examples: The lighthouse stood on a rocky promontory above the harbor
Waves crashed against the promontory during the storm
From the promontory, they surveyed the entire valley below
The ancient fortress occupied a strategic promontory position
